title: 108_hr482
content:
The Act titled "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" and "State" as the Secretary of Agriculture and the State of Florida, respectively. It also addresses the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange parcels of Federal land in Florida, including specific tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties. Tracts in Okaloosa County include various parcels such as A-942d, A-943, A-944, and A-945, with different acreages and descriptions. Several tracts of land in Florida are up for sale or exchange, including parcels in Okaloosa County such as A-945, a Landfill-Golf Course Driving Range spanning 40.85 acres in Crestview. Other tracts include vacant lots in Liberty County and land in Lake County. Several tracts of land in Lake County, Florida are available for sale or exchange, including parcels described by their acreage and specific locations within the county. Several tracts of land in Lake County, Florida are available for sale or exchange, including parcels ranging from approximately 15 to 79.58 acres in size. The locations and descriptions of these tracts are specified in detail, such as T. 18 S., R. 28 E., sec. 14, SE1/4 SW1/4 and T. 13 S., R. 25 E., sec. 22. The Secretary may modify land descriptions for sale or exchange based on a survey or public interest. Offers can be solicited for land sale or exchange, with the Secretary having the authority to reject offers. The Secretary has the authority to reject offers for the sale or exchange of land if they are deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The land described in subsection (b) can be sold at public or private sale, with the option to use a real estate broker and pay them a comparable commission. (g) The Secretary of the Air Force must approve the sale or exchange of land described in subsection (b). (h) Cash equalization may be accepted if non-Federal land's value is lower than Federal land exchanged. (i) Net proceeds from any sale or exchange under this Act go to the fund established by Public Law 90-171. Amounts deposited in the fund established by Public Law 90-171 (``Sisk Act'') shall be used by the Secretary for land acquisition and reimbursement of costs related to land sales and exchanges under this Act. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION.

Land acquired by the United States under this Act shall be subject to the Weeks Act and administered according to laws applicable to the National Forest System. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws.
